Chrysalis Fund Search Join Certification News Blog Store Log in Breadcrumb Home About ESA Meet the ESA Staff How can we help you? Click each picture to view that ESA staff member's contact info and bio. Not sure who to contact? Send us a question through our contact form and we'll get it to the right staff member. Chris Stelzig, Executive Director Rosina Romano, Chief Operating Officer Stacie East, Director of Grants and Ethics Erin Cadwalader, Director of Strategic Leadership and Policy Josh Lancette, Director of Publications Joe Rominiecki, Director of Marketing and Communications Alexis Lyons, Senior Accountant Cindy Myers, Associate Director of Partnerships, Programs, and Events Becky Anthony, Associate Director of Programs and Meetings Mary Campbell, Senior Membership, Database & Analytics Manager Danielle Tempesta, Meetings Manager Willet Hossfeld, ICE-CCP, Certification Programs Manager Rebecca Martin, Certification & Strategic Initiatives Coordinator Jessica McEwan, Managing Editor Irene Nudd, Publications Coordinator Meaghan-li McArdle, Grants and Program Support Coordinator Caitlyn Maltese, Marketing and Web Manager Alison Howard, Marketing Coordinator Executive Director Chris Stelzig, CAE cstelzig@entsoc.org 1-301-731-4535 x3012 he/him Contact Chris about: Governing Board | ESA governance | ESA strategy | Code of Conduct | ethics concerns Chris has enjoyed working with ESA in a wide array of management areas since March 2000, including science policy, certification, membership, data management, and strategy. Today he leads the headquarters office as the executive director. He is ESA's primary liaison between staff and governance as well as serving as a primary point of contact for the society on many allied groups. Chris' education and background is in marketing, and he came to ESA from serving eight years in the newspaper industry. He has stayed with ESA for so many years because he is a firm believer in the mission of the Society and the opportunities for insect science to make the world a better place through the strategic principles of social responsibility, global impact, and increasing influence. He is a frequent volunteer for a variety of philanthropic organizations and has served on the board of local Annapolis charities. He was born in Fargo, ND, grew up in Morgantown, WV, and now lives within walking distance of the ESA headquarters office. Favorite insect: Mantids. Really pretty much anything from Mantodea [ back to top ] Chief Operating Officer Rosina Romano, CMP, DES rromano@entsoc.org 1-301-731-4535 x3010 Contact Rosina about : everything Annual Meeting │your membership experience │Code of Conduct Rosina brings members together to share their passion for insects. As the Chief Operating Officer, she leads staff in creating memorable experiences throughout the year leading up to the society's Annual Meeting in November. Rosina specializes in nonprofit conference planning, starting part-time with her first association in 1999. She first fell in love with supporting their annual legislative conference. Since then, Rosina has worked for a variety of membership organizations, steadily increasing the size and scope of their conferences and events. Prior to joining ESA, Rosina was the director of meetings and events at the National Association of County and City Health Officials (NACCHO), managing a team of four planners hosting 60 meetings a year. Born in Alabama, Rosina grew up in southern Virginia. She earned her bachelor's degree in international affairs (2001) and her master's in tourism administration (2009) both from the George Washington University. In 2010 she earned the Certified Meeting Professional designation from the Events Industry Council. Favorite insect : "Fireflies. You should see our backyard in the summer!" [ back to top ] Director of Grants and Ethics Stacie East, CAE seast@entsoc.org 1-301-731-4535 x3030 Contact Stacie about: PHEFA | diversity, equity, and inclusion │ EntoMentos │ Diversity & Inclusion Committee Stacie spearheads ESA's efforts related to member access. She practiced law for more than 25 years after graduating from Yale Law School and the University of Chicago. She has extensive professional association volunteer experience, and has served on a number of association committees, task forces, and boards. In addition, Stacie was recently the director of a diversity pipeline program and served as associate director of diversity and inclusion at the California Western School of Law. In her downtime, Stacie lifts weights and hikes. Favorite insect : June bug [ back to top ] Director of Strategic Leadership and Policy Erin Cadwalader, Ph.D. ecadwalader@entsoc.org 1-301-731-4535 x3025 Contact Erin about: Science policy and advocacy | Leadership Development | Elections Erin leads the Society's science policy and advocacy efforts, including the Grand Challenges Agenda for Entomology, as well as overseeing leadership development programs like the Professional Advancement Career Training (PACT) program and elections. She is a key liaison between ESA and many allied groups and leads the Vector-Borne Disease Network, a coalition that advocates for support for vector research, surveillance, and management. Before joining the ESA staff, Erin worked with the Society for several years as the leading voice for ESA on Capitol Hill as an external consultant and lobbyist. While her background is in biomedical research, she transitioned from the bench to the science policy community in D.C. more than a decade ago and has worked on a wide range of advocacy issues related to scientific research and workforce development, higher education, and social justice for organizations such as Research!America, the Association for Women in Science, and Lewis-Burke Associates LLC. She is passionate about the importance of evidence-based policymaking and ensuring science and research are part of the conversation. Erin grew up on the East Coast and in the Midwest. She earned her bachelor's degrees in biochemistry and molecular biology from the University of Wisconsin-Madison and her Ph.D. in neurobiology and anatomy from the University of Utah. After slowly drifting westward, she now calls Maryland home. Favorite insect: Western Hercules Beetle [ back to top ] Director of Publications Josh Lancette jlancette@entsoc.org 1-301-731-4535 x3020 Contact Josh about: ESA's publications | ESA's editorial boards and Publications Council | how to publish a book with ESA Josh directs the strategy and operations of ESA's family of research journals and its quarterly magazine, as well as the Society's book-publishing program. He got started in publishing as the managing editor of the Journal of Insect Science , working with Henry Hagedorn, Ph.D., at the University of Wisconsin. When ESA purchased the journal in 2014 after Hagedorn passed away, Josh came along with it and joined the staff of ESA to begin working on all ESA's titles, eventually rising to the role of managing editor. From 2022 to late 2024, he worked as managing editor at the Infectious Diseases Society of America. Working remotely from Minneapolis, Josh also lived in Wisconsin and Colorado before ending up back in his home state. Favorite insect: Dragonflies. [ back to top ] Director of Marketing and Communications Joe Rominiecki, CAE jrominiecki@entsoc.org 1-301-731-4535 x3009 Contact Joe about: ESA website and email | Entomology Today | social media | media relations | Better Common Names Project Joe helps ESA members engage with their professional society and tell their stories about insect science. He oversees the Society's marketing strategy and website operations and also manages key external communication channels, including Entomology Today , social media, and public relations. Trained as a writer and editor, Joe originally had sportswriting in his scopes but found the mission-driven and service-oriented environment of nonprofit membership organizations highly motivating during nine years at Associations Now , the member magazine of the American Society of Association Executives. His work there brought him face to face with the best and brightest ideas in association management, an experience he has brought to his role in marketing and communications for ESA. Joe was born in Philadelphia, grew up in Ohio, and earned his bachelor's degree in journalism at Ohio University (2005). Today he works remotely for ESA from western Connecticut. Favorite insect: Ticks ("I know, not an insect, and it's more of a morbid fascination, particularly living in New England.") [ back to top ] Senior Accountant Alexis Lyons alyons@entsoc.org 1-301-731-4535 x3017 Contact Alexis about: vendor payments | membership payments | refunds Alexis helps ESA members with payments that need to be made to the Society, ranging from membership renewals to Annual Meeting payments. She also helps facilitate any refund requests. When not helping the members, Alexis assists the director of finance with monthly and annual reporting and regular day-to-day accounting functions. Trained in accounting business finance, Alexis started her career with major audit firm Deloitte and Touche. Her path has led her into the nonprofit realm, where she values being involved with an organization that has a meaningful mission to her. While she may not keep a bee hive at her house, she recognizes the importance of our pollinator population and is happy to whatever she can do to support the scientists that love them. Favorite insect: Glass-winged butterfly [ back to top ] Associate Director of Partnerships, Programs, and Events Cindy Myers, DES cmyers@entsoc.org 1-301-731-4535 x3001 Contact Cindy about: exhibiting | Corporate Partner Program | awards | Student Affairs Committee | Annual Meeting logistics Cindy builds relationships with ESA's Corporate Partners and helps them reach their marketing goals by connecting them with ESA members. She also fills the exhibit hall yearly with exciting and interesting exhibitors for Annual Meeting attendees. She loves planning and organizing, which shows each year during the Annual Meeting. Along with the meetings team, she executes the onsite logistics of the meeting, including registration, student volunteers, security, and the exhibit hall. Cindy grew up in Maryland and earned her bachelor's degree in marking at Salisbury State University (2000). Cindy joined ESA in 2012 and brought with her more than 12 years of hotels sales and conference planning experience. Favorite insect: " Scarab beetle (but only the pretty ones)" [ back to top ] Associate Director of Programs and Meetings Becky Anthony, CMP, DES banthony@entsoc.org 1-301-731-4535 x3018 Contact Becky about : Annual Meeting | submissions | registration | Branches | Branch meetings Becky manages the scientific program for the ESA Annual Meeting and serves as the primary staff liaison for ESA Branches, providing strategic and logistical support to the leadership. Becky began her career in the food and beverage industry, where she worked for several years before transitioning to meeting planning. Her position with ESA combines her love of planning and logistics with her service-oriented personality, allowing her to connect personally with a large number of members throughout the Society. A longtime resident of Baltimore, Maryland, you can frequently find Becky at the ballpark to catch an Orioles games or headed to the beach. She earned her bachelor's degree at Carson-Newman University in 2002. In 2018, she earned the Certified Meeting Professional designation from the Events Industry Council. Favorite insect: Butterflies [ back to top ] Senior Membership, Database & Analytics Manager Mary Campbell mcampbell@entsoc.org 1-301-731-4535 x3013 Contact Mary about : membership │ data inquiries │ elections Mary helps ESA members take full advantage of all the benefits the society has to offer. Her focus is to promote engagement and ensure that members are satisfied. She also provides support for key member programs and manages ESA's relationship with its outside database provider. Mary was drawn to nonprofit association work, as an opportunity to support the mission of organizations she feels passionately about. Prior to joining ESA, Mary provided membership and constituent services support at Trout Unlimited, the Greater Maryland Chapter Alzheimer's Association, and the Natural Resources Defense Council. Mary grew up in Annapolis, Maryland. She earned her bachelor's degree in Animal Science from the University of Maryland (2014). Favorite insect : "Honey bee, but I'm grateful to all pollinators for their good deeds!" [ back to top ] Meetings Manager Danielle Tempesta dtempesta@entsoc.org 1-301-731-4535 x3029 Contact Danielle about : Annual Meeting │ Branch Meetings | submissions │ registration │ webinars │ membership inquiries Danielle supports the ESA Annual Meeting, Branch Meetings, and ESA's webinar series. She also assists with general membership inquiries. Danielle began her career working in the events department of a science museum, and then moved to Chicago to work in the event department of the Field Museum of Natural History. While at the Field Museum, Danielle volunteered in the Division of Insects digitizing the collection inventory, with a focus on Cerambycidae and Tingidae. Prior to joining ESA, she was recently working on tech conferences. Born in New York City, Danielle later grew up in Florida, and earned her bachelor's degree in Event Management from the Rosen College of Hospitality Management at UCF. Danielle currently lives in Central Florida where you can find her riding her bike, reading a book, or spending time outside in the garden. Favorite insect: Orchid mantis - for their beauty and speed [ back to top ] Certification Programs Manager Willet Hossfeld, ICE-CCP whossfeld@entsoc.org 1-301-731-4535 x3026 Contact Willet about : everything certification-related | BCE | ACE | ACE-International Willet leads the charge for ESA's Certification Programs, helping individuals quantify and demonstrate their arthropod understanding, whether they are pest management professionals or entomologists looking to specialize their knowledge. Willet began working with certification programs in 2009 while working as a software vendor for various medical associations. Willet made the transition to working for an association in 2013 and has overseen the development, support, and update of several certification programs. He is an advocate for certifications in whatever aspect of life is relevant, believing they serve as a concise, easily understandable way for the general public to understand an individual's expertise. He joined ESA in 2017 to oversee the BCE and ACE programs and has enjoyed his crash course in entomology and pest management, having minimal exposure to either prior to joining ESA. Born and raised on Long Island in New York, Willet earned his bachelor's degree in Spanish and Latin American Studies from Hobart College in 2006. When he's not working, he prefers to spend as much time outside as possible, preferably on the water. Favorite insect : "It's a toss-up: The white witch moth and rhinoceros beetle were two of the first insects I really learned anything about, and the orchid bee is just such a cool looking bee, sort of metallic blue/green." [ back to top ] Certification & Strategic Initiatives Coordinator Rebecca Martin rmartin@entsoc.org 1-301-731-4535 x3054 they/them Contact Rebecca about : All Certification Programs Rebecca works with the Certification Programs Manager to help individuals quantify and demonstrate their arthropod understanding, whether they are pest management professionals or entomologists looking to specialize their knowledge. They also assist the Director of Strategic Initiatives. Rebecca was drawn to the mission of ESA and the opportunity to support the important work of championing insect biodiversity and sustainable pest management practices. Prior to joining ESA, they worked as an educator and in the literary nonprofit sector, where they have a background in creative and academic writing. They are excited to continue supporting access to education and knowledge in the Certification Programs at ESA. Rebecca is originally from Ohio, but now calls Pittsburgh home. They earned a B.A. from the University of Pittsburgh (2018) and an M.F.A. from Oregon State University (2022). Favorite insect : Luna moth [ back to top ] Managing Editor Jessica McEwan jmcewan@entsoc.org 1-301-731-4535 x3024 Contact Jessica about: journals | ScholarOne | publishing | peer reviewing Jessica oversees the day-to-day operations of the ESA journals and assists with strategic planning. Jessica believes that high-quality research is critical to the preservation of our planet's delicate ecosystems. She is motivated by the ESA's mission to enable members to share their science globally and she enjoys helping authors and editors publish impactful research. Prior to ESA, Jessica spent 15 years with the Society for Vascular Surgery where she helped to launch, grow, and manage a portfolio of journals. Jessica earned her bachelor's degree in journalism from Keene State College. She lives in her hometown of Canaan, New Hampshire, and spends her free time cooking, reading, and hiking in the White Mountains. Favorite insect: Snowberry clearwing [ back to top ] Publications Coordinator Irene Nudd inudd@entsoc.org 1-301-731-4535 x3028 Contact Irene about: general inquiries | journal information | manuscript updates | peer-review | ScholarOne | American Entomologist | Insect Calendar Committee Irene assists in managing ESA's scholarly journals through a variety of administrative and creative tasks. From communicating with authors on manuscript statuses to working on projects to improve the flow of publication, her main priority is supporting those who volunteer their time and work for the advancement of entomological research. Irene received a B.A. in English from George Mason University and has always had an interest in publishing. She got started in publishing as an editorial intern at the Gastroenterological Association and developed a passion for journal publishing. From there, she went on to become the American Geophysical Union's first publications intern. Originally from Woodbridge, Virginia, Irene is currently located in Richmond, Virginia. Favorite insect: Periodical cicadas ( Magicicada septendecim ). ("I wish I could take a 17-year nap.") [ back to top ] Grants and Program Support Coordinator Meaghan-li McArdle mmcardle@entsoc.org Contact Lili about: Public Health Entomology for All | grants | diversity, equity, and inclusion Meaghan-li, or Lili, works with the Director of Grants and Ethics to provide support for ESA's diversity, equity, and inclusion efforts, including the Public Health Entomology for All (PHEFA) internship and fellowship program. She is excited about the opportunity to make sure entomology, and the wider STEM field, is accessible to all. Lili is from Chicago, Illinois, and received a B.S. in economics, international business, and marketing from Saint Louis University – Madrid, where she gained a passion for promoting environmental sustainability in business. In her free time, Lili enjoys indoor rock climbing, hiking, camping, and attempting to learn different musical instruments. Favorite insect: Hine's emerald dragonfly (for its adventurousness). [ back to top ] Marketing and Web Manager Caitlyn Maltese cmaltese@entsoc.org 1-301-731-4535 x3022 Contact Caitlyn about: ESA website | email Caitlyn has a passion for helping mission-driven organizations connect with their audiences and inspire action through strategic marketing, compelling storytelling, and data-driven engagement. She manages ESA's marketing strategy, website operations, and multi-channel campaigns to enhance brand visibility and member experiences. Trained as a writer and designer, Caitlyn specializes in creative communication. Her path into the nonprofit realm started with sharing a love of books and promoting educational equity. Through her work, she strives to harness the transformational power of storytelling to foster understanding, spark change, and build more inclusive, informed communities. She is inspired by how insect science can support a more sustainable, biodiverse world. A Maryland native, Caitlyn earned her degree from Washington College, where she graduated early with honors. When she's not working, you'll find her reading, tending to her garden, or spending time with her pets (and trying to convince her husband to adopt more). Favorite insect: Chubby bumble bees [ back to top ] Marketing Coordinator Alison Howard ahoward@entsoc.org 1-301-731-4535 x3021 Contact Alison about: ESA email | social media Alison supports marketing and communications efforts across ESA, helping tell the story of the Society and its members. Prior to joining ESA, she held communications roles in the nonprofit and sustainable development sectors. She grew up in South Florida and earned her bachelor's degree in English language and literature at the University of Chicago. She is currently based in Washington, DC. Favorite insect: "While they are officially terrestrial crustaceans, I think roly-polies (aka pillbugs) are very cute!" A hidden gem and best-kept secret in Southwest Florida, greens are rated amongst the best in the region. Just 10 minutes from Southwest Florida International Airport. Playing at 7,072 yards from its championship tees, the par 72 course sits on 105 lush acres surrounded by 38 acres of sparkling lakes. The course features six sets of tees to challenge the skills of players at every level. They also offer an outstanding practice range, as well as large putting and chipping greens. Very challenging but user-friendly for both advanced or beginner golfer. In addition to golf, the community includes a fitness center, five lighted Har-Tru Tennis courts, two pickleball courts and two bocce courts. Also, there are multiple league options for both golf and tennis. Finally, all residents of The Vines are required to have at least a Social Membership. All membership types, Social, Sport, and Golf, are available for non-residents. The course is located on 550 acres of home sites, beautiful lakes, and preserves. This private community offers residents a variety of single-family homes, villas, carriage homes, and condominiums. Further, residents can also join the club as Golf, Sports, or Social Members. Additionally, the focal point of the community is the 18-hole Darwin Sharpe III designed par 72 golf course. Further, the course is a natural sanctuary for oak and pine trees, marshes, and wildlife. Ultimately, players of all levels can challenge themselves on this beautiful course with undulating greens, rolling fairways, and sharp elevations. In addition to the course, the club offers excellent practice facilities such as a driving range, putting green and short game area. Finally, residents will enjoy Tennis Courts, a Community Pool, a fitness center, Bocce Ball, Basketball courts, and an active social calendar. Vines Homes & Condos For Sale Estero Florida The Vines of Estero is an established community of 440 residences behind its gated, secured entrance. The Vines community offers single family homes, coach homes, attached villas, and condominiums of various designs and styles.  The Vines has a home to fit any real estate need. Within the gates of The Vines you will find smaller neighborhoods each featuring their own pool.  One of the best benefits living in The Vines offers is the sweeping views, generous lot size and large lakes with bridges to each neighborhood.  The Vines is one of the few communities with a spacious feel and a little room to enjoy nature.  The distances between the estate homes is larger than most neighborhoods, similar to Wildcat Run and Spanish Wells . All residents of The Vines are also eligible for membership in the Estero Country Club. Belle Lago owners are also eligible to join Estero Country Club. Estero Country Club at The Vines offers a number of social, fitness and golf amenities including: A par 72, Gordon Lewis designed course One thousand square foot fitness center with both cardiovascular and strength training equipment. The fitness center is accessible 24 hours a day for our members to workout at their convenience. Tennis facilities: With five lighted Har-Tru courts, our tennis professional provides lessons, clinics, tiny-tots and junior programs. Pickleball Courts Sports bar Elegant dining room The Vines is conveniently located just minutes to Southwest Florida International Airport, Coconut Point Mall, Gulfcoast Town Center and just a short drive to the white, sugar sand beaches of Bonita Beach , located in Bonita Springs, Florida .  The nearby Estero Community Center offers an off-leash dog park. If you are interested in purchasing or selling a home in The Vines, please contact Chris Griffith at 239-273-7430. Private Country Club Estero, FL Skip to main content MENU ☰ × Click to Search Login × About Us Testimonials FAQ Latest News Blog Membership Membership Inquiry Membership Application What People Are Saying Golf Amenities Contact Us Real Estate Realtor Information Master HOA Resident Information Property Leases Local Associations FAQs Charitable Foundation History Focus Charities Champions Drive Annual Fundraiser The Private Country Club Estero, Fla., Residents Love AN ARNOLD PALMER SIGNATURE COURSE Established in 1985, Wildcat Run Golf & Country Club is a gated community of only 450 homes featuring exceptionally large, private lots and beautiful landscaping. Located between Naples and Fort Myers in beautiful Southwest Florida, Wildcat Run is ‘tucked away in the middle of everything.’ Immerse yourself in the ultimate golfing experience at our newly renovated, 18-hole Arnold Palmer signature golf course in the heart of Estero. From challenging fairways to lush greenery, our course, designed by the legendary Arnold Palmer, offers a golfing paradise. After a day on the course, indulge in exquisite dining options. Members enjoy a fine dining experience in our clubhouse, where culinary delights await in a sophisticated atmosphere. Or unwind in the Grill Room for a more casual and laid-back setting , where you can savor delicious meals and drinks in a relaxed environment. Wildcat Run's state-of-the-art practice facilities cater to golfers of all levels, ensuring you can refine your skills and elevate your game. Wildcat Run Golf & Country Club is proud to celebrate its' 40th anniverary in 2025, and invite you to learn more about our club. Experience the Pride! If you would like to learn more about Wildcat Run Golf & Country Club, please contact us today at (239) 948-7810 or email membership@wildcatruncc.com for membership opportunities. Real Estate Explore Real Estate GOLF Unquestionably the most famous name in golf, and in partnership with Ed Seay, Arnold Palmer designed Wildcat Run to be challenging, yet fair, for players of all levels. The wide and rolling fairways are without equal in terms of natural beauty. Set among native palms, oaks and cypress preserves, the par-72 layout was completely renovated in 2023, and offers six different sets of tees ranging from 4,342 to 6,912 yards. An extensive practice area renovation also offers a complete practice experience. Explore The Course AMENITIES Our 18-hole, par-72 Arnold Palmer-designed signature golf course is a jewel. The course is challenging, yet player-friendly and rated one of the best in Southwest Florida. Take advantage of group or private lessons from our top-notch teaching staff. A spacious clubhouse comfortably accommodates the many dining and social activities of this vibrant community. The Clubhouse is an ideal setting for exquisitely prepared meals in our formal dining room and cocktail lounge. In addition, we have a renovated, casual Grill Room that is the perfect gathering place to relax with old friends or meet new ones at the adjacent pair of bocce courts. Tennis players enjoy four Har-Tru courts with a variety of clinics and mixers, and four new Pickleball courts offer fun for all ages. No matter what your racquet game level, there’s a match for you at Wildcat Run. Our contemporary Fitness and Wellness center offers the latest exercise equipment and trained staff for group or private instruction. Explore Amenities Resident Golf Memberships Available Please inquire about Non-Resident golf waitlist opportunities. Explore Memberships (239) 947-6066 WILDCAT RUN GOLF & COUNTRY CLUB 20300 Country Club Dr. Estero, FL 33928-2037 © Wildcat Run Golf & Country Club. All Rights Reserved.
